definition:
Let $\Sigma \subset \Gamma$ be a subgroup where $\Gamma$ is a compact
Lie Group acting on a vector space $V$. The *fixed-point subspace* of
$\Sigma$ is
$$\operatorname{Fix}(\Sigma) = \{ x \in V \mid \sigma x = x,\; \forall \sigma \in \Sigma\}$$
$\operatorname{Fix}(\Sigma)$ is a linear subspace of $V$ since
$$\operatorname{Fix}(\Sigma) = \bigcap_{\sigma \in \Sigma} \operatorname{ker}(\sigma - \operatorname{I})$$
where $I$ is the identity. If it is important to specify the space $V$
we use the following notation $\operatorname{Fix}_V(\Sigma)$.

[1]{} Golubitsky, Martin. Stewart, Ian. Schaeffer, G. David:
Singularities and Groups in Bifurcation Theory *(Volume II)*.
Springer-Verlag, New York, 1988.
